title: 104_hr4016
content: The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" is cited as the short title. It amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include State Grants for Drug and Violence Prevention Programs. The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" reserves funds for specific programs, including grants for Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, and the Northern Mariana Islands, programs for Indian youth, a national impact evaluation, and programs for Native Hawaiians. State allotments are allocated based on specific criteria. The Secretary allocates funds among states based on population and previous funding received, with a minimum allotment set. Funds can be reallotted if a state cannot use them within two years. The Secretary can reallot funds to a State if they cannot be used within two years. Definitions include 'State' as the 50 states, DC, and Puerto Rico, and 'local educational agency' includes educational service agencies and consortia. "SEC. 4112. STATE APPLICATIONS." To receive funding under section 4111, the State's chief executive officer must submit an application to the Secretary. The application must outline how funds will be coordinated with other programs, provide results of a needs assessment for drug and violence prevention, assure cooperation with national impact evaluations, and include any additional information required by the Secretary. The Secretary will review State applications using a peer review process. "State programs under SEC. 4113 require the State's chief executive officer to submit an application outlining fund coordination, needs assessment for drug and violence prevention, cooperation with national impact evaluations, and any additional information needed by the Secretary." The chief executive officer of a State must use allocated funds for drug and violence prevention programs. Administrative costs are limited to 5% of the total amount received. Grants and contracts must be used exclusively for prevention or education programs focused on the dangers of illegal drug use and underage drinking. The allocated funds must be used solely for drug and violence prevention programs, with strict penalties for any misapplication of funds. Grants can be awarded to law enforcement agencies for education partnerships. The chief executive officer can use funds to award grants to law enforcement agencies for education partnerships focused on drug abuse and violence prevention activities. This includes programs like Drug Abuse Resistance Education, Project Legal Lives, partnerships with child guidance professionals, and before- and after-school activities. "SEC. 4114. EVALUATION AND REPORTING." The Secretary conducts a biennial evaluation of national impact of programs combating violence in schools, collecting data on violence frequency and seriousness in elementary and secondary schools. A report with recommendations is submitted to the President and Congress. The Secretary shall submit a report to Congress by January 1, 2000, with recommendations and estimated costs for implementing them. States must submit reports on their programs under section 4113 every third year, including data on drug use and violence by youth, which must be made public. The Secretary will provide grants to organizations serving Native Hawaiians recognized by the Governor of Hawaii to administer programs for their benefit. Native Hawaiian is defined as individuals with ancestors native to Hawaii before 1778.
